title: Hard Problems Are Still Hard: How Changing Tools Keep Colliding With the Same Old Work

paragraphs.content: Figma’s December 2025 post “Hard problems are still hard: A story about the tools that change and the work that doesn’t” captures a growing sentiment across tech: artificial intelligence is transforming workflows, but not dissolving the underlying difficulty of the work itself.In that piece, Figma product manager Nikolas Klein recounts building new AI-powered image editing tools and concludes that even with powerful models, core design challenges like judgment, trade‑offs, and context remain stubbornly human.A similar refrain appears in robotics coverage, where commentators note that as agentic AI systems spread through automation and manufacturing, they intensify long‑standing problems of planning, safety, and integration rather than resolving them.Together these perspectives frame a 2025 reality in which tools change quickly, yet the hardest problems in software, design, and robotics continue to resist easy fixes.

paragraphs.content: Beyond Figma, the phrase “hard problems are still hard” now anchors broader debates about AI’s real limits, from the mechanics of deploying agentic systems in enterprises to enduring gaps in AI reliability and accuracy.Commenters on forums such as TravellerRPG argue that despite striking advances in language and image models, progress on genuinely hard AI problems—like robust reasoning or dependable perception—remains modest once systems are pushed outside narrow demos.At the same time, Figma’s own AI roadmap, including credits systems and integrations that promise faster work, underscores how commercial tools are racing to wrap these imperfect capabilities in usable product experiences rather than claiming to have solved creativity itself.The tension between accelerated tooling and persistent difficulty has become a defining storyline for how practitioners and investors judge the next wave of AI products.

sections.title: Design, AI, and the Stubbornness of Real Creative Work

paragraphs.content: Figma’s flagship essay argues that while AI now handles tasks like image cleanup and layout suggestions, it does not answer the hardest design questions about what to build, for whom, and why.The post situates these challenges alongside other Figma writing on AI, which stresses that tools can reduce friction in production but cannot replace the need for understanding user context and orchestrating complex collaboration.Outside consumer design, a Manning book chapter on large language models uses nearly identical language—“hard problems are still hard”—to describe why LLMs follow S‑curves of diminishing returns and remain bounded by data, compute, and fundamental computational limits.That chapter warns against assuming generative models will spontaneously self‑improve into general problem‑solvers, arguing instead that they are best deployed on “fuzzy” tasks where approximate answers are acceptable rather than on problems demanding precision and guarantees.

paragraphs.content: In software engineering, game developer Ryan Fleury reaches a parallel conclusion in his exploration of multithreading and mutation, writing that “hard problems are still hard” even after he adopted better abstractions.Fleury explains that once concurrency enters the picture, seemingly simple tasks become complex because programmers must manage data races, shared state, and opaque interactions that invalidate many single‑threaded intuitions.His proposed response is not a new silver‑bullet tool but deliberate constraint: designing systems and APIs that make unsafe patterns impossible and force engineers to grapple with complexity up front rather than during late‑stage rewrites.This echoes the LLM analysis, which suggests that tools can shift where the effort lands, but do not remove the need for careful system design and human reasoning about edge cases and failure modes.

sections.title: Robots, Agentic AI, and the Long Tail of Unsolved Problems

paragraphs.content: Robotics reporting in late 2025 repeatedly illustrates how impressive demos mask unresolved fundamentals, from perception to planning. A Robotics.ee archive for October highlights ongoing work on planetary exploration robots and emphasizes that coping with uncertainty—noisy sensors, unpredictable terrain, and limited communication—is a core, unsolved challenge despite better hardware and algorithms.Another Robotics.ee piece from December, based on interviews with autonomous vehicle safety staff, describes how teams still struggle to manage and share safety data effectively, suggesting that organizational and socio‑technical hurdles remain as stubborn as purely technical ones.A Manning chapter on LLM limits reinforces this picture by noting that while models can aid code generation and high‑level reasoning in robotics stacks, they do not magically solve long‑horizon control or formal safety verification, where guarantees and rigorous testing are still required.

paragraphs.content: Enterprise AI commentary pushes this argument into the boardroom, with DataRobot’s discussion of agentic AI warning that moving from static assistants to autonomous workflows actually sharpens problems around governance, reliability, and aligning systems with business value.The company cites research showing that most generative‑AI pilots fail to yield measurable impact at scale, attributing this not just to immature models but to difficult design and integration work that automation cannot shortcut.Security‑focused outlets such as Open Source Security further remind practitioners that even as AI‑driven tools promise to detect vulnerabilities faster, longstanding issues like dependency risk and long‑term maintenance—highlighted in their discussions of Kubernetes and related projects—continue to demand sustained expert attention. Across these domains, the message is consistent: new tools, from robot sensors to generative agents, can change who does which part of the work and how quickly, but the deepest problems of safety, coordination, and judgment remain as hard as ever.
